Figure 10: Diagram showing the assembled lid frame being placed over the assembled tray. A label indicates 'ASSEMBLE LID FRAME AND FIT TO TRAY'.

projects.name: Card Holder

steps.instruction: Cut the base (E) to match the lid frame size.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a lid frame and a base piece, with an arrow indicating the base should be cut to match the lid frame.

steps.instruction: Mount the base to the bottom of the tray so there's an even overhang on all four edges.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing the tray frame aligned on top of the base, with arrows indicating alignment and gluing.

steps.instruction: Align the tray using the lid frame as a guide. Place the lid frame over the base and mark the inside circumference.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a pencil tracing the inside perimeter of the lid frame onto the base.

steps.instruction: Glue the tray to the base. Use a board on top of the tray edges to even out the pressure of the C-clamps.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing the tray frame glued to the base, with C-clamps and a board on top for even pressure.

steps.instruction: Carve symbols for the four suits on the lid top (H). Figure 18 is a full-size pattern.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a lid top with two rectangular pads glued to the underside. Also shows a router bit and a chisel working on the edge of the lid.

steps.instruction: Cut two 1/2" thick hold-down pads (I) and glue them to the underside of the lid top, centered over each tray.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing the bottom side of the lid with two rectangular pads glued to it, centered over where the trays will be.

steps.instruction: Glue the lid top (H) to the lid frame. After it's dry, sand the outside perimeter of the box until the surfaces of the top, lid frame, and base are flush.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing the lid being placed on the tray, with an arrow indicating sanding the outside perimeter.

steps.instruction: Use the router table to rout a 1/4" chamfer all the way around the top edge of the lid. Use a chisel to clean up the corners.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a router bit chamfering the top edge of the lid, and a chisel cleaning up a corner.

steps.instruction: Drill shallow holes for the felt pads on the bottom of the base. Locate the centerpoints of the holes 1/4" from each edge.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing the bottom of the base with arrows indicating the placement of felt pads and dimensions for drilling holes.

steps.instruction: Mount felt pads to the bottom of the tray.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing felt pads being placed on the bottom corners of the base.

steps.instruction: Sand all surfaces of the card holder smooth and apply the finish (three coats of Sutherland Welles Tung Oil).
steps.visual_description: None

tips: The easiest way to even out the pressure of the C-clamps was to make a "sandwich" by placing a board on the top edges of the tray.
As the decks are used, they tend to "puff up." These pads help keep the cards in the trays and prevent them from sliding over the center divider.
It may be necessary to do some additional sanding for a better fit.
The router bit won't quite fit into the corners, so you had to clean them up with a chisel.

projects.name: Producing Thin Stock on a Table Saw

steps.instruction: Cut each piece about 6" longer than needed so the ends can be cut off after the piece is resawn.
Rough cut the stock to about 1/16" thicker than the final thickness you want.
steps.visual_description: Figure 2 shows rough cutting stock on a table saw.

steps.instruction: Raise the saw blade no more than 1½" on the first cut, and position the fence to cut the stock 1/16" thicker than the final thickness needed.

Use a large push stick to feed the board through the blade, keeping the board tight against the fence. Then flip the piece end for end (so the same face is still against the fence) and make a second cut on the opposite edge.
steps.visual_description: Figure 3 shows a sequence of cuts on a board, illustrating flipping the piece end for end.

steps.instruction: On stock that's 3" wide or less, try to complete the resawing with the second pass. If the stock is too wide for two cuts, raise the blade in ½" increments and run both edges through the saw a second time.
As the final cuts are made, push the board through the blade without hesitating. This will help prevent burning. Then flip the stock end for end to complete the trimming cut.
steps.visual_description: Figure 4 shows making final cuts in two passes using a featherboard.

steps.instruction: If the stock is cupped at all, it will probably spring back as soon as it clears the featherboard. The result is that the blade will gouge the last couple of inches at both ends of the board. Simply cut off both ends to remove the areas affected.
steps.visual_description: Figure 5 illustrates using a featherboard to flatten cup in stock, showing adjustments for concave and convex cuts. Figure 6 shows an end view of a piece of stock that is longer than needed, with a note to remove ends after resawing.

tips: The actual height of the blade for the first pass should be varied according to the species of wood and the horsepower of the motor on your table saw.
Very often the stock will develop a minor cup after the first cuts. If this happens use a featherboard to hold the board flat against the fence.
Set up the featherboard just ahead of the blade.
If the stock is cupped toward the fence, raise the position of the featherboard to the center of the board.
If the stock is cupped away from the fence, keep the featherboard flush with the table top and push the top edge against the fence as the cut is made.
Start with longer pieces than needed.

diagram_descriptions: Figure 1: Diagram showing how to build a resawing fence to straddle the rip fence. It indicates a 6" height for the resawing fence.
Figure 2: Illustration of rough cutting stock on a table saw, with a hand pushing the wood.
Figure 3: A sequence of five diagrams (labeled 1 through 5) showing the process of resawing a board, including flipping the piece.
Figure 4: Illustration of making final cuts in two passes on a table saw, using a featherboard.

Figure 5: Two diagrams illustrating the use of a featherboard to flatten cupped stock. The left diagram shows the featherboard low for a concave cup, and the right diagram shows it high for a convex cut.
Figure 6: An end view of a piece of stock that is longer than needed, with a note indicating that the ends should be removed after resawing.
